ai-ud3.6:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-ud3.6:1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Pilindavaccha was adding the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’.
ai-ud3.6:1.4_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud3.6:1.4_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-ud3.6:2.1_0: Then the Fortunate One addressed a certain monk, (saying):
ai-ud3.6:2.2_0: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Pilindavaccha that
ai-ud3.6:2.4_0: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Pilindavaccha,
ai-ud3.6:2.4_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Pilindavaccha:
ai-ud3.6:3.1_0: “Yes, reverend,” Pilindavaccha replied. He went to the Buddha, and told him.
ai-ud3.6:3.3_0: “Is it really true, Vaccha, that you addressed the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’?”
ai-ud3.6:4.1_0: Then the Buddha focused on Pilindavaccha’s previous lives, addressed the mendicants:
ai-ud3.6:4.2_0: “You should not be offended, monks, at the monk Vaccha,
ai-ud3.6:4.3_0: He doesn’t addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’ out of hate.
ai-ud3.6:4.4_0: For five hundred lives without interruption he was reborn in a brahmin family.
ai-ud3.6:4.5_0: for a long time he has addressed people as ‘lowlife’.
ai-ud3.6:4.6_0: That’s why he addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’.”
ai-ud3.6:5.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud3.6:6.1_0: “In whom dwells no deceit or conceit,
ai-ud3.6:6.2_0: He who is free from lust, unselfish, not yearning,
ai-ud3.6:6.4_0: they are a brahmin, an ascetic, a mendicant.”
ai-ud3.6:6.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
